qas.question: In 1770, who reported that Medri Bahri was a distinct political entity from Abyssinia?
What determined whether The Bahre-Nagassi fought with or against the Abyssinians?
Which century marked the arrival of the Ottomans?
Where did the Ottomans come from?
Who was the ruler of Bahre-Nagassi?
In what year did Abyssinia collapse?
In what year did Ahmad ibn Ibrahim al-Ghazi of Adal die?

context: The <a0_0>Scottish traveler<a0_0/> <a1_0>James Bruce<a1_0/> reported in <b6_0>1770<b6_0/> that Medri Bahri was a distinct political entity from Abyssinia, noting that the two territories were frequently in conflict. The Bahre-Nagassi (<a2_0>"Kings of the Sea"<a2_0/>) alternately fought with or against the Abyssinians and the neighbouring Muslim Adal Sultanate depending on the <a3_0>geopolitical circumstances<a3_0/>. Medri Bahri was thus part of the Christian resistance against <b7_0>Imam Ahmad ibn Ibrahim al-Ghazi<b7_0/> of Adal's forces, but later joined the Adalite states and the Ottoman Empire front against <b5_0>Abyssinia<b5_0/> in <b8_0><b9_0>1572<b9_0/><b8_0/>. That <a4_0>16th<a4_0/> century also marked the arrival of the Ottomans, who began making inroads in the Red Sea area.
